What did you find difficult about spending time with your child? ğŸ”‘
It can be hard to find time during your day, with work, chores, and everything else.
âœ¨Think of a time each day that you could spare 5 minutes. You can even make household chores into a game to do together.
ğŸ˜” It can be sad when your child does not want to spend one-on-one time with you.
ğŸ’¡ Think to yourself: When are they more interactive to you? In the morning? Right before bedtime?

ğŸ“º Children often want to spend time watching T.V. or playing with a gadget.
â“ You could watch or play on the gadget with them.
ğŸ’šCaring about their interests is a great start!
ğŸŒ· Once you begin spending time together you can suggest another activity.
Type {PLAY} for a fun activity suggestion.
â˜€ï¸ If your child wants to do things that are too difficult for you to do, you could watch them.
ğŸ You could describe what they are doing like a sports announcer.
ğŸ’› Praise them while they do it!
âš½ Competitive games can be hard for children (and adults!) if they donâ€™t like losing.
ğŸ† When they have calmed down, talk with your children about what winning well and losing well might look like.
ğŸ“ Suggest other activities that you can do to work together instead of against each other.
Type {PLAY} for a fun activity suggestion. ğŸ’¡
ğŸ”´ It can be difficult to spend one-on-one time with each child when you have more than one child.
ğŸŒ± If possible, you can ask an adult or older sibling to look after the other children while you spend one-on-one time with your child.
â° Think of when it would be easier to spend one-on-one time with each child.
ğŸ’› You can also spend one-on-one time with all of your children at once!

What did you find difficult when supporting your childâ€™s development?
ğŸŒˆ It is okay to feel that way. But there are many small ways to spend time with your child!

â° You can interact with your child while doing something else. For example, you can ask your child to describe the colours and objects they see around them while you are walking together or in transit on a bus.
ğŸ˜ƒ Your child will appreciate the attention you are giving, even for a short while.
ğŸ˜£ You may be sad because your child does not want to spend time with you.
â° Sometimes, your child just needs time to engage with you. It helps to remain calm, patient, and kind while you try to connect with your child.
ğŸŒ± As children grow, they may want independence from you. Thatâ€™s normal! You can support them to find friends based on their interests.
Here is more information about supporting child development:
{development resources 2}
ğŸ§¸ It must be hard to see your child getting injured or feeling sad often.
ğŸŒ·Children learn and grow from making mistakes. It is an important part of child development. They will be safe as long as you are aware of their activities and you can prevent anything dangerous.
â­ Build your childâ€™s confidence about their abilities, values, and appearance so that they are comfortable trying new things.
ğŸ¨ Encourage them to safely try out fun activities with other kids or adults. Praise them when they do it well!
ğŸ’š Let your child know that you trust them to be safe and follow the rules that you have set.
âš½ Competitive games can be hard for children (and adults!) if they donâ€™t like losing or sharing.
ğŸ† When they have calmed down, talk with your child about what winning well and losing well might look like.
ğŸ’™ It must be difficult when your child is expressing negative feelings, but this is common because your child is also learning to manage their emotions.
ğŸ‘‚ Listen to your childâ€™s emotions and acknowledge them.
ğŸ’¡ Ask your child how to feel better and give your child advice on what you think would work well.
ğŸŒ± While it is tempting to solve your childâ€™s problems immediately with what you think is best, it will not help them grow.
ğŸ’š We are sorry to hear that it has been hard for you to understand your childâ€™s development.

What did you find hard about involving your child when creating household rules and routines?
ğŸ“– When creating rules, it is important to think about the age of each child, so you can come up with routines that are fair for their age.
â° This is most important for bedtime, the time to come home, and household chores.
â­ Our children learn best from us.
âœ… The more we follow the rules, the more they will follow the rules too.
ğŸ’› You can adapt the rule to make sure that it is something everyone can follow.
ğŸŒ· When we create rules together with our children, we build trust and an open relationship with them.
ğŸ”‘ The rules we set will be more realistic and your child will be more willing and able to follow the rule.

What did you find hard about managing your childâ€™s behaviour?
ğŸŒ± Next time, try to catch the misbehaviour early on, before it sets in or gets worse.
ğŸ‘‚ Talk to them about this behaviour when both of you feel calmer.
ğŸŒ± It is normal to sometimes get angry at our children when they are misbehaving, especially when they are driving us crazy.
â¸ Next time, take a deep breath and take some space.
â˜€ï¸ Later, find something small and clear that your child is doing and you wish they could do more of. Then, praise them when they do it.
ğŸ’š This must be very stressful for you. Please remind yourself that you are trying your best.
ğŸŒ· You may need to spend more one-on-one time with your child to have a stronger relationship with them.
â­ Give more positive attention to them when they are behaving well - even the smallest good behaviour - and praise them for this behaviour.
ğŸŒ™ Be patient. Learning to manage our behaviour takes time!
ğŸŒ· It is normal to sometimes get angry at our children when they are misbehaving, especially when they are driving us crazy. The important thing is how we manage that anger.
â¸ First, slow down. You can type {PAUSE} at any time to review the Slow Down lesson.
ğŸ’š Be kind to yourself. You are both learning and itâ€™s okay not to get it right all the time.
ğŸŒ± When you feel calmer, you could apologise to your child for shouting and remind them that you love them.
ğŸˆ Repeat the core message of what you were trying to say in a calmer way.
ğŸ’š Thatâ€™s okay, this is all about learning!
ğŸ’¡ When you give your child a choice, you teach them decision-making skills.
âœ¨ It does not always work, but when it does, it helps avoid giving them a consequence later!
ğŸŒ· Sometimes, your child will react in a negative way when receiving a consequence.
âœ¨ Walk away until they calm down.
ğŸ’¡ As long as the consequence is fair, it is important to follow through with it, even if they are angry.
Here are 3ï¸âƒ£ three tips to remember if your childâ€™s behaviour is persisting:
1ï¸âƒ£ Your child will act out negatively to get attention if they are not getting positive attention. Try to praise your childâ€™s positive behaviour when you see it.
2ï¸âƒ£ Remain consistent when ignoring behaviours. Inconsistency may confuse children and reinforce negative attention seeking behaviours.
3ï¸âƒ£Consider whether the behaviour is age appropriate.Your child may be too young for difficult tasks, like remaining quiet while you are talking to a friend.

Remember that building a positive relationship with your child and giving your child positive attention when they are behaving well is the best way to reduce negative behaviours! If youâ€™ve completed the Goal â€œImprove my Relationship with My Childâ€ you can type {REVIEW} to review tips for praise and talking about your feelings together. â­
We are sorry to hear that it has been hard to manage your childâ€™s behaviour. You can review this skill in the Main Menu any time! ğŸ“
What did you find hard about keeping your child safe online and offline?
ğŸ“º It must be exhausting to always tell your child to turn off or put away the gadgets.
ğŸ“ You can set rules with your child. Tell them that they cannot be on gadgets when you are busy. Your busy time is your childâ€™s quiet play time with toys or reading time with books.
ğŸŒ· Tell your child that sharing what they watch on T.V. or what they do on gadgets is a rule.
ğŸ‘‚ Be patient and kind while listening to them. Manage your anger if you find that they did something wrong online. Take a deep breath.
ğŸ’› Praise your child when they follow the rules!
ğŸ… It is common for children to refuse vegetables and fruits, especially when tastier but less healthy food options are available all around us.
ğŸŒ± You could encourage your child to eat slightly sweeter fruits and vegetables for a start, such as mangos and sweet tomatoes. You can gradually introduce other vegetables and fruits.
ğŸˆ Praise you child even when they take one mouthful of vegetables or fruits!
ğŸ‘‚ Thatâ€™s alright, even adults donâ€™t agree on this sometimes. Listening to our children, even when we disagree, helps us understand their thinking.
â° Find time to talk about safe unsafe areas again.
ğŸ’š This time, really listen and show you understand their view before sharing your thoughts.
ğŸ“ Tell your child that you appreciate their opinions and you are proud of them for being honest about how they feel.
ğŸ˜” It is shocking to learn that people who we trust may cause discomfort to our children.
ğŸ‘‚ Listen to your child if they want to talk about why it seems dangerous or uncomfortable. Trust what they say - they will not say such things for no reason!

SourceText: All children behave badly sometimes. Here are a list of typical behaviours that can be challenging for parents. Which one describes the most challenging for you to manage with your child?
Learning how to manage our stress is the first step to providing the best support for our children. Letâ€™s check in on you first:
Do you feel overwhelmed by the responsibility of being a parent? ğŸ˜”
That is great to hear! ğŸ‰
That is okay. We will learn more about taking time for ourselves today.
Before we get started on your goal to have a healthy relationship with your family members, please answer this question:
Do you and your family members share caregiving and household tasks equally? â°
That is okay. You will learn more about the importance of sharing caregiving and household tasks in this goal
Thatâ€™s great to hear! Sharing tasks equally helps everyone feel valued.
What did you find difficult about sharing tasks equally?
ğŸŒ± Ask them! Telling your family members you want to help but donâ€™t know how, shows them you care and want to be involved.
â° Try creating a routine. Planning when to do household tasks or ways to share caregiving can be a helpful reminder.
ğŸ”‘ Once you start sharing tasks more often - it will will get easier to remember.
ğŸ”‘ It can be hard to ask for help. Sometimes we expect our family members to know we need help even if we donâ€™t ask them.
ğŸŒ± Once you start telling, they are more likely to help again in the future.
ğŸŒ± Finding time to help, and ask for help, can be hard.
